title: Joshua Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 7.

questions.question: Who took of the accursed thing, causing the anger of the LORD against Israel?
options: Achan
Joshua
Zabdi
Carmi
questions.correctAnswer: Achan
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:1 states that Achan, son of Carmi, took of the accursed thing, leading to the LORD's anger.

questions.question: Where did Joshua send men from Jericho to spy?
options: Ai
Bethel
Bethaven
Shebarim
questions.correctAnswer: Ai
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:2 says Joshua sent men from Jericho to Ai to view the country.

questions.question: How many men did the spies suggest should attack Ai?
options: Two or three thousand
Ten thousand
Five hundred
All the people
questions.correctAnswer: Two or three thousand
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:3 indicates the spies recommended only about two or three thousand men go up to smite Ai.

questions.question: What happened to the men of Israel who went to Ai?
options: They fled before the men of Ai
They captured Ai
They made a treaty
They were victorious
questions.correctAnswer: They fled before the men of Ai
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:4 states the three thousand men fled before the men of Ai.

questions.question: How many men of Israel were killed by the men of Ai?
options: Thirty-six
One hundred
Twelve
Fifty
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty-six
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:5 records that thirty-six men were smitten by the men of Ai.

questions.question: What was Joshua's reaction after Israel's defeat at Ai?
options: He rent his clothes and fell before the ark
He fled the battlefield
He celebrated
He prayed silently alone
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his clothes and fell before the ark
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:6 describes Joshua tearing his clothes and falling on his face before the ark of the LORD.

questions.question: What did Joshua say to the LORD regarding the defeat?
options: He asked why God brought them over Jordan to be destroyed
He thanked God for protection
He asked for riches
He made a vow to build an altar
questions.correctAnswer: He asked why God brought them over Jordan to be destroyed
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:7 records Joshua lamenting and questioning why God brought the people over Jordan to be delivered into the hands of their enemies.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 7:11, Israel had stolen and hidden the accursed thing among their own belongings.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:11 confirms that Israel sinned by taking the accursed thing and hiding it among their own possessions.

questions.question: What did the LORD command Israel to do to be able to stand before their enemies?
options: Destroy the accursed thing from among them
Offer more sacrifices
Build a wall
Form an alliance
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy the accursed thing from among them
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:12 commands that the accursed thing must be destroyed to have the LORD's presence and stand before enemies.

questions.question: According to Joshua 7:14, how was the accursed person to be identified?
options: By tribes, families, households, and man by man
By age and gender
By wealth and rank
By their place of birth
questions.correctAnswer: By tribes, families, households, and man by man
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:14 explains the process of bringing Israel by tribes, families, and households to find the accursed person.

questions.question: Who was identified as the person with the accursed thing?
options: Achan
Zabdi
Zerah
Joshua
questions.correctAnswer: Achan
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:18 identifies Achan, son of Carmi, as the one taken with the accursed thing.

questions.question: What items did Achan confess to taking?
options: A Babylonish garment, two hundred shekels of silver, and a wedge of gold
A sword and shield
Grain and cattle
A scroll and staff
questions.correctAnswer: A Babylonish garment, two hundred shekels of silver, and a wedge of gold
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:21 shows Achan confessed to taking these specific items.

questions.question: Where were the stolen items found?
options: Hidden in Achan's tent
Buried under a tree
In the camp's treasury
With the elders
questions.correctAnswer: Hidden in Achan's tent
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:22 reveals the stolen items were hidden in Achan’s tent, with silver under it.

questions.question: What was done to Achan after his sin was revealed?
options: He was stoned and burned with fire
He was forgiven
He was imprisoned
He was sent away
questions.correctAnswer: He was stoned and burned with fire
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:25 describes that Achan and his possessions were stoned and burned as punishment.

questions.question: True or False: The place where Achan was punished was named The valley of Achor.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:26 states the place was named The valley of Achor after Achan's punishment.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'And Joshua said, My son, give, I pray thee, glory to the LORD God of Israel, and make _________ unto him; and tell me now what thou hast done.'
options: confession
offering
prayer
sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: confession
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:19 records Joshua asking Achan to make confession to the LORD.

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to take what does not belong to them. Based on Joshua 7, what biblical truth would you share about integrity?
options: Taking what is accursed brings God's anger and consequences
God overlooks small sins if no one finds out
It is acceptable to keep spoils if you give some to God
Sin only affects the individual, not the community
questions.correctAnswer: Taking what is accursed brings God's anger and consequences
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:1, 11-12 show that Achan took the accursed thing, provoking God's anger against Israel, leading to defeat and judgment. This teaches the importance of honesty and integrity.

questions.question: How does Joshua demonstrate humility and dependence on God after Israel's defeat at Ai?
options: He rents his clothes, falls to the ground, and prays before the ark
He blames the soldiers for their cowardice
He immediately plans a bigger army attack
He ignores the defeat and moves on
questions.correctAnswer: He rents his clothes, falls to the ground, and prays before the ark
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:6-9 shows Joshua humbling himself before God, seeking His guidance in prayer, which teaches believers to depend on God in trials.

questions.question: What does God's command to sanctify the people before identifying the sinner teach us about spiritual discipline?
options: Preparation and holiness are essential before confronting sin
Punishment must be immediate without preparation
Only leaders need to be sanctified for spiritual battles
Sanctification is optional in resolving conflicts
questions.correctAnswer: Preparation and holiness are essential before confronting sin
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:13 instructs sanctifying the people to be holy before discovering the accursed thing, emphasizing the need for spiritual readiness.

questions.question: What lesson about confession and repentance can be learned from Achan's response when confronted?
options: Confessing sins openly brings accountability and clarity
Denying sin protects one's reputation
Hiding sin is acceptable if it benefits the community
Repentance is unnecessary if God is not angry
questions.correctAnswer: Confessing sins openly brings accountability and clarity
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:19-20 shows Joshua urging Achan to confess, and Achan admits his sin, teaching the importance of honest confession.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to covet material possessions. How does Joshua 7 warn about the consequences of coveting?
options: Coveting leads to sin that brings judgment and affects many
Coveting is harmless if not acted upon
Coveting is a sign of ambition blessed by God
Coveting only harms the individual
questions.correctAnswer: Coveting leads to sin that brings judgment and affects many
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:21 and 25 show Achan's coveting caused sin and brought trouble upon Israel, teaching that coveting has serious spiritual consequences.

questions.question: Based on Joshua 7, what is the importance of obedience to God's commands in the life of a believer?
options: Disobedience invites God's anger and hinders spiritual victory
Obedience is optional depending on circumstances
God rewards disobedience if intentions are good
Obedience is only for priests and leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience invites God's anger and hinders spiritual victory
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:11-12 explains Israel's sin broke God's covenant causing their defeat, showing obedience is crucial for God's blessing.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and honesty can be learned from how Achan hid the stolen items?
options: Dishonest gain leads to hidden shame and eventual exposure
Hiding possessions protects a person from judgment
Stewardship is irrelevant if items are taken in war
Honesty is only required in public, not private matters
questions.correctAnswer: Dishonest gain leads to hidden shame and eventual exposure
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:21-22 shows Achan hid stolen spoils in his tent, but they were discovered, teaching that dishonesty cannot be concealed from God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 7, the entire community suffers consequences when one member sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:12 states Israel could not stand before enemies because of one person's sin, showing community impact of individual sin.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua's leadership included seeking God's direction and confronting sin openly in the community.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:6-9 and 7:19-20 show Joshua praying for guidance and confronting Achan, modeling godly leadership.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joshua 7 teaches that before a believer can overcome sin, they must first ______ themselves.
options: sanctify
ignore
hide
justify
questions.correctAnswer: sanctify
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:13 instructs the people to sanctify themselves before removing sin, highlighting the need for holiness in overcoming sin.

questions.question: What does the story of Achan teach about the relationship between family and accountability in the church community?
options: Sin affects the entire household and community, requiring collective accountability
Family members are never held accountable for one person's sin
Only the individual is responsible for their actions
Sin should be ignored to maintain family peace
questions.correctAnswer: Sin affects the entire household and community, requiring collective accountability
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:24-25 includes Achan's family and possessions in judgment, showing sin’s communal effect and accountability.

questions.question: How does Joshua 7 guide believers in dealing with trials and discouragement?
options: Seek God in prayer humbly and trust His direction
Avoid facing the problem and move on quickly
Rely on human strength and strategy alone
Blame others for the trouble
questions.correctAnswer: Seek God in prayer humbly and trust His direction
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:6-10 shows Joshua's response to defeat was humble prayer and seeking God's will, teaching perseverance through dependence on God.

questions.question: What does the naming of the Valley of Achor teach about God's justice and mercy?
options: God’s judgment brings eventual restoration and remembrance
God forgets sins immediately without consequence
God's justice is harsh with no possibility of mercy
The place was named for a great victory only
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment brings eventual restoration and remembrance
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:26 explains the valley's name marks judgment but also the turning away of God's anger, showing justice paired with mercy.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach about the importance of leadership and accountability in the church?
options: Leaders must confront sin and lead the community in obedience
Leaders should ignore sin to keep peace
Accountability is only for common members, not leaders
Leadership is about popularity, not discipline
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must confront sin and lead the community in obedience
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:19-20 shows Joshua directly addressing Achan's sin, exemplifying godly leadership and accountability.

questions.question: Why was the initial attack on Ai unsuccessful, and what does it teach about trusting God’s commands?
options: Because of hidden sin, Israel was cursed and defeated
The enemy was too strong for Israel
Israel had too few soldiers
Joshua made a poor battle plan
questions.correctAnswer: Because of hidden sin, Israel was cursed and defeated
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:4-5 and 11-12 explain Israel's defeat was due to Achan’s sin causing God’s anger, teaching the necessity of obedience and purity.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 7.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for Israel's defeat at Ai according to Joshua 7?
options: Achan took of the accursed thing
They attacked with insufficient forces
Joshua did not consult God
The Amorites were stronger
questions.correctAnswer: Achan took of the accursed thing
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:1 states that Israel's trespass in taking the accursed thing caused the LORD's anger, leading to their defeat.

questions.question: According to Joshua 7, what was the condition for the LORD to remain with the Israelites after their sin?
options: Destroy the accursed from among you
Offer a sacrifice at the tabernacle
Cross the Jordan again
Pray for forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy the accursed from among you
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:12 explains that God would not be with them unless they removed the accursed thing from among them.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the method of identifying the guilty party in Joshua 7:14-18, where the search narrows from tribes to families to households to individuals?
options: Chiasm
Parallelism
Typology
Gradual narrowing (inclusio)
questions.correctAnswer: Gradual narrowing (inclusio)
questions.explanation: The passage uses a progressive narrowing method to isolate the guilty individual, a literary technique to emphasize thoroughness (Joshua 7:14-18).

questions.question: In Joshua 7:21, Achan confesses to coveting and taking certain items. What is the significance of the 'Babylonish garment' mentioned here in a historical-cultural context?
options: Indicates trade connections or spoils from a distant region
Represents royal priestly garments
Symbolizes idolatry of Babylon
A common local garment of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: Indicates trade connections or spoils from a distant region
questions.explanation: The Babylonish garment suggests cultural and trade interactions beyond Canaan, highlighting the value and foreign origin of the spoil (Joshua 7:21).

questions.question: What does the Hebrew word translated as 'accursed' (Hebrew: חרם, cherem) in Joshua 7 most closely imply?
options: Dedicated to destruction or set apart for God
Forbidden yet allowed for sacrifice
A blessing for the people
Common property of the tribe
questions.correctAnswer: Dedicated to destruction or set apart for God
questions.explanation: The term 'cherem' refers to items or people devoted to God by complete destruction, emphasizing the seriousness of Achan’s sin (Joshua 7:1, 11).

questions.question: Which Old Testament covenant is Joshua referring to when he mentions Israel transgressing it in Joshua 7:11?
options: The Mosaic Covenant at Sinai
The Abrahamic Covenant
The Davidic Covenant
The Noahic Covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The Mosaic Covenant at Sinai
questions.explanation: The covenant broken is the Mosaic law given at Sinai, which included strict commands about holy war and the accursed things (Joshua 7:11).

questions.question: How does the stoning and burning of Achan and his possessions in Joshua 7:25 foreshadow New Testament themes of purification and judgment?
options: It typifies the need for holiness and removal of sin to restore community
It symbolizes baptism by fire in the Spirit
It prefigures Christ’s crucifixion
It represents resurrection from death
questions.correctAnswer: It typifies the need for holiness and removal of sin to restore community
questions.explanation: The severe judgment illustrates the seriousness of sin and the necessity of purging evil to maintain covenant relationship, paralleling NT calls for holiness (Joshua 7:25).

questions.question: True or False: Joshua’s act of rending his clothes in Joshua 7:6 is an expression of both personal and communal mourning and repentance common in ancient Near Eastern culture.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:6 shows Joshua and the elders mourning by tearing clothes and putting dust on their heads, a known ancient sign of grief and repentance.

questions.question: According to Joshua 7:9, what was Joshua's concern regarding Israel’s reputation among the Canaanites and other inhabitants?
options: That Israel’s name would be cut off from the earth
That Israel would gain too much fame
That Israel would form alliances with Canaanites
That Israel would abandon their God
questions.correctAnswer: That Israel’s name would be cut off from the earth
questions.explanation: Joshua feared that defeat would cause Israel’s enemies to destroy their reputation and identity (Joshua 7:9).

questions.question: What intertextual connection can be drawn between Joshua 7 and Deuteronomy 20 regarding the handling of the accursed things?
options: Both require the destruction of accursed things to maintain covenant purity
Both describe the conquest of Jericho
Both focus on the role of the priests in war
Both provide laws about dividing spoils
questions.correctAnswer: Both require the destruction of accursed things to maintain covenant purity
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20 commands destruction of certain spoils to avoid defilement, paralleling Joshua 7’s emphasis on removing the accursed to maintain God's favor.

questions.question: Which theme prominent in the Pentateuch is emphasized by God’s refusal to be with Israel due to sin in Joshua 7:12?
options: God’s holiness and the necessity of covenant obedience
The promise of a land inheritance
The institution of the priesthood
The giving of the Ten Commandments
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holiness and the necessity of covenant obedience
questions.explanation: God’s withdrawal underscores His holiness and the requirement that His people obey the covenant to enjoy His presence (Joshua 7:12).

questions.question: What is the significance of the naming of the 'valley of Achor' in Joshua 7:26 in light of biblical typology?
options: It represents a place of trouble turning into a place of hope
It marks the site of Israel’s first temple
It signifies the defeat of the Amorites
It symbolizes a place of divine judgment only
questions.correctAnswer: It represents a place of trouble turning into a place of hope
questions.explanation: The name 'Achor' means 'trouble'; its naming commemorates judgment yet also God's turning away anger, foreshadowing restoration (Joshua 7:26).

questions.question: In Joshua 7:19-20, Joshua invites Achan to confess. How does this interaction highlight the role of leadership in ancient Israel?
options: Leaders were intercessors and sought confession to restore covenant relationship
Leaders acted as military commanders only
Leaders performed sacrifices for sins
Leaders judged only after appeals
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders were intercessors and sought confession to restore covenant relationship
questions.explanation: Joshua’s request for confession shows leadership’s role in mediating between the people and God for restoration (Joshua 7:19-20).

questions.question: Which cultural practice does Joshua 7:24-25 reflect regarding communal responsibility for individual sin in ancient Israel?
options: Collective punishment including family and possessions
Individual exile without family involvement
Trial by ordeal
Offering a sin offering on behalf of the sinner
questions.correctAnswer: Collective punishment including family and possessions
questions.explanation: Achan’s whole household and possessions were punished, reflecting communal responsibility and purity laws (Joshua 7:24-25).

questions.question: True or False: The initial reconnaissance by Joshua’s men to Ai (Joshua 7:2-3) demonstrates a strategic military approach uncommon in the conquest narratives.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua’s sending of spies to Ai shows deliberate military reconnaissance, a tactic not always explicit in conquest stories (Joshua 7:2-3).

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for Israel's defeat at Ai as described in Joshua Chapter 7?
options: They did not have enough men to fight
They committed a trespass by taking the accursed thing
The Amorites had superior weapons
Joshua was not leading the army
questions.correctAnswer: They committed a trespass by taking the accursed thing
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:1-12 explains that Israel's defeat was due to sin within the camp, specifically Achan's taking of the accursed thing, which brought God's anger and caused Israel to be accursed and defeated. This aligns with the biblical principle that sin separates from God's blessing (1 Samuel 15:23; Proverbs 13:15; Isaiah 59:2; Romans 6:23).

questions.question: Who was identified as the individual responsible for taking the accursed thing?
options: Achan, son of Carmi
Zabdi, son of Zerah
Joshua, son of Nun
The king of Ai
questions.correctAnswer: Achan, son of Carmi
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:1 specifically names Achan, son of Carmi, as the one who took the accursed thing, causing Israel's sin and defeat. This highlights the biblical teaching on individual responsibility for sin (Ezekiel 18:20; Galatians 6:5; James 1:14-15; 1 Corinthians 10:12).

questions.question: According to Joshua, what was the consequence of Israel's sin for their standing before their enemies?
options: They would be exalted above all nations
They would turn their backs and flee before their enemies
They would receive immediate forgiveness
They would conquer Ai with ease
questions.correctAnswer: They would turn their backs and flee before their enemies
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:8-12 describes how Israel's sin caused them to turn their backs in battle and flee, demonstrating the principle that sin leads to spiritual and practical defeat (Psalm 37:12-13; Proverbs 16:18; Isaiah 59:2; James 4:7).

questions.question: What does Joshua's reaction of tearing his clothes and falling on his face before the ark symbolize?
options: Joy and celebration
Repentance and mourning
Confusion and doubt
Anger towards Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance and mourning
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:6 shows his deep repentance and mourning before God, which is consistent with biblical expressions of grief over sin (2 Samuel 1:11-12; Ezra 9:5-6; Nehemiah 1:4; Jonah 3:6). This act exemplifies humility before God.

questions.question: What does God command Israel to do in order to restore His favor and stand before their enemies?
options: Offer more sacrifices
Sanctify themselves and remove the accursed thing
Build a larger army
Send a prophet to Ai
questions.correctAnswer: Sanctify themselves and remove the accursed thing
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:13 directs Israel to sanctify themselves and remove the accursed thing, illustrating the biblical principle of holiness and separation from sin to maintain fellowship with God (Leviticus 20:7; 1 Peter 1:16; Hebrews 12:14; 2 Corinthians 6:17).

questions.question: How was the tribe, family, and household identified as guilty according to the method used in Joshua 7?
options: By casting lots
By prophetic revelation
By voting of the elders
By examination of their possessions
questions.correctAnswer: By casting lots
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:14-18 describes the use of casting lots to identify the tribe, family, and individual guilty of sin, reflecting the biblical use of lots as a means of discerning God's will (Leviticus 16:8; Proverbs 16:33; Acts 1:26; Jonah 1:7).

questions.question: What items did Achan confess to taking that were forbidden?
options: A golden calf and silver idols
A Babylonish garment, silver, and a wedge of gold
A sword and shield from Ai
Grain and wine from the spoil
questions.correctAnswer: A Babylonish garment, silver, and a wedge of gold
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:21 records Achan's confession of taking a Babylonish garment, two hundred shekels of silver, and a wedge of gold, highlighting the biblical prohibition against coveting and stealing devoted things (Exodus 20:17; Deuteronomy 7:25-26; 1 Corinthians 10:20).

questions.question: What theological truth is demonstrated by the statement that the LORD’s anger was kindled against Israel?
options: God is indifferent to sin
God is holy and just, and sin provokes His wrath
God always forgives immediately
God does not punish corporate sin
questions.correctAnswer: God is holy and just, and sin provokes His wrath
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:1 reveals God's anger against Israel's sin, teaching the attribute of God's holiness and justice that must address sin (Nahum 1:2-3; Romans 1:18; Hebrews 12:29; Revelation 15:4). This also underscores the seriousness of sin in God's covenant community.

questions.question: What does the execution of Achan and his family illustrate about the covenant community’s responsibility towards sin?
options: Only the individual sinner is responsible
The community must remove sin to maintain purity
Sin is ignored for the sake of unity
Punishment is always private and hidden
questions.correctAnswer: The community must remove sin to maintain purity
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:24-25 shows that Achan, his family, and possessions were destroyed, demonstrating that sin affects the whole community and must be dealt with corporately to preserve covenant purity (Leviticus 20:2-5; 1 Corinthians 5:6-7; Hebrews 12:15; 2 Corinthians 7:1).

questions.question: What does the name 'The valley of Achor' signify theologically?
options: A place of victory and joy
A place of trouble and judgment turned to hope
A place of exile for the Israelites
A place where God abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: A place of trouble and judgment turned to hope
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:26 states that the valley was called 'The valley of Achor,' meaning 'trouble,' marking the place of judgment that also served as a turning point toward God's mercy. This prefigures biblical themes of judgment bringing hope (Hosea 2:15; Isaiah 43:2; Romans 5:3-5; Revelation 21:4).

questions.question: What does the failure of Israel to stand before their enemies teach about the consequences of sin in spiritual warfare?
options: Sin has no effect on spiritual victory
Sin causes defeat and loss of God's presence
God fights for Israel regardless of sin
Spiritual warfare is won by human strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Sin causes defeat and loss of God's presence
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:12 highlights that Israel's sin caused them to be accursed and lose God's presence, leading to defeat. This reflects the biblical truth that sin hinders God's protection and victory in spiritual battles (Psalm 66:18; 1 Samuel 15:22-23; 2 Chronicles 7:14; Ephesians 6:12-13).

questions.question: What does Joshua's prayer in verses 7-9 reveal about his understanding of God's holiness and reputation?
options: He was only concerned about Israel's losses
He recognized God's name and reputation were at stake
He doubted God's power to save
He blamed the Amorites alone
questions.correctAnswer: He recognized God's name and reputation were at stake
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:7-9 shows Joshua lamenting not only Israel's plight but God's great name being dishonored, teaching that God's holiness and reputation are central to covenantal faithfulness (Exodus 20:7; Isaiah 48:9; Ezekiel 36:22-23; Romans 2:24).

questions.question: What doctrine is highlighted by God's statement that He will not be with Israel anymore until the accursed is removed?
options: The doctrine of unconditional election
The doctrine of God's presence contingent on holiness
The doctrine of predestination
The doctrine of universal salvation
questions.correctAnswer: The doctrine of God's presence contingent on holiness
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:12 teaches that God's presence and blessing depend on the people's holiness and obedience, affirming that fellowship with God requires purity (Exodus 33:15-16; Leviticus 11:44; Psalm 24:3-4; Hebrews 12:14).

questions.question: How does the method of identifying the sinner in Israel connect to God's justice and mercy?
options: It shows arbitrary punishment without evidence
It ensures the guilty are exposed for repentance and removal of sin
It punishes entire tribes regardless of guilt
It ignores sin for the sake of peace
questions.correctAnswer: It ensures the guilty are exposed for repentance and removal of sin
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:14-19 illustrates a just process by which God exposes the sinner, allowing for confession and repentance, thus providing a way to cleanse the community. This aligns with biblical justice and mercy principles (Numbers 5:6-7; 2 Chronicles 30:18-20; John 8:3-11; 1 John 1:9).

questions.question: What Christological theme can be linked to the removal of sin from Israel in Joshua 7?
options: The need for a human king
The necessity of a sinless mediator who removes sin
The importance of military conquest
The promise of earthly riches
questions.correctAnswer: The necessity of a sinless mediator who removes sin
questions.explanation: The removal of sin and the curse in Joshua 7 prefigures Christ as the sinless mediator who removes sin from God's people (Hebrews 9:14; 1 John 3:5; Isaiah 53:5-6; Romans 8:3-4). Achan's judgment illustrates the consequences of sin that Christ alone can atone for.

questions.question: What does the burial of Achan and his possessions signify in the context of covenant theology?
options: The forgiveness of all sins without penalty
The seriousness of covenant violation requiring removal of sin
The acceptance of sinful practices in the community
The irrelevance of obedience to God
questions.correctAnswer: The seriousness of covenant violation requiring removal of sin
questions.explanation: Joshua 7:24-26 shows that covenant violation demands serious consequences, including removal of sin and sinners to restore the community's holiness and fellowship with God (Exodus 32:27-29; Leviticus 16; 1 Corinthians 5:7-8; Hebrews 10:26-29).
